Abstract

In this paper, we consider the following graph embedding problem: Given a bipartite graph G=(V1,V2;E)ğºsubscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2ğ¸G=(V_{1},V_{2};E)italic_G = ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_E ), where the maximum degree of vertices in V2subscriptğ‘‰2V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 4, can GğºGitalic_G be embedded on a two dimensional grid such that each vertex in V1subscriptğ‘‰1V_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn as a line segment along a grid line, each vertex in V2subscriptğ‘‰2V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn as a point at a grid point, and each edge e=(u,v)ğ‘’ğ‘¢ğ‘£e=(u,v)italic_e = ( italic_u , italic_v ) for some uâˆˆV1ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘‰1u\in V_{1}italic_u âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vâˆˆV2ğ‘£subscriptğ‘‰2v\in V_{2}italic_v âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn as a line segment connecting uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v, perpendicular to the line segment for uğ‘¢uitalic_u? We show that this problem is NP-complete, and sketch how our proof techniques can be used to show the hardness of several other related problems.

Technical Report SOCS-TR-2006.1, September 2006

1 Introduction

Orthogonal graph drawing is a well studied area in the graph drawing community, and one may find many applications in VLSI design. In this paper, we study orthogonal drawings of bus graphs, which represent interconnectivity of functional entities in a chip. In VLSI layouts, a bus is a line segment drawn on a plane. To establish a connection among a collection of buses, a connector is drawn as a point on the plane, and then joined to the buses by line segments. Thus, the interconnections of the buses can be represented by a bipartite graph, where one partition of vertices corresponds to the set of buses, and the other corresponds to the set of connectors. We call such bipartite graphs bus graphs, and we are interested in the problem of drawing bus graphs on the plane.

For manufacturing purposes, it is desired that all the buses and the edges that join them are laid out either horizontally or vertically. Furthermore, it is also necessary to lay out the components of a chip, i.e. buses and connectors, sufficiently far from each other. Thus, we wish to draw the bus graph on a grid, where each bus is laid out along a grid line, and each connector is drawn at a grid point. Each edge between a bus and a connector is also drawn along a grid line. In particular, an edge joining a bus is drawn as a line segment perpendicular to the bus. We do not allow any edge to intersect with any connectors or buses, except at endpoints of the edge. However, a horizontal edge may cross a vertical edge. Thus, each connector can connect at most 4 buses. We define the combinatorial bus graphs as the class of bipartite graphs G=(â„¬,ğ’;â„°)ğºâ„¬ğ’â„°G=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ), where the degree of connector vertices in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is at most 4.

We say a (combinatorial) bus graph GğºGitalic_G is realizable if GğºGitalic_G can be drawn while meeting the conditions above. See Fig.Â 1 for an example of a bus graph and its realization. We now formally define the Bus Graph Realizability (BGR) problem as follows:

Instance: A bipartite graph G=(â„¬,ğ’;â„°)ğºâ„¬ğ’â„°G=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ) such that âˆ€câˆˆğ’for-allğ‘ğ’\forall c\in\mathcal{C}âˆ€ italic_c âˆˆ caligraphic_C, degâ¡(c)â‰¤4degreeğ‘4\deg(c)\leq 4roman_deg ( italic_c ) â‰¤ 4.

Question: Can GğºGitalic_G be drawn onto a grid so that the following properties hold?

  1. 1.

    Each vertex Bâˆˆâ„¬ğµâ„¬B\in\mathcal{B}italic_B âˆˆ caligraphic_B is drawn as a closed line segment along a grid line.

  2. 2.

    Each vertex câˆˆğ’ğ‘ğ’c\in\mathcal{C}italic_c âˆˆ caligraphic_C is drawn as a point at a grid point.

  3. 3.

    Each edge (B,c)âˆˆâ„°ğµğ‘â„°(B,c)\in\mathcal{E}( italic_B , italic_c ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E is drawn as a closed line segment between BğµBitalic_B and cğ‘citalic_c, that is perpendicular to BğµBitalic_B, and contains no other connectors or buses apart from BğµBitalic_B and cğ‘citalic_c; an edge can, however, cross other edges as shown in Fig.Â 1. An edge may connect to a bus at an endpoint of the bus.

  4. 4.

    No buses or connectors may intersect.

Now we are ready to state our main result.

Theorem 1.1

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2, we give definitions and preliminaries. A proof of our main theorem is given in Sect. 3. In Sect. 4, we show that the techniques we use to prove TheoremÂ 1.1 can be applied to related problems. In Sect. 5, we look at a variation of the problem where the lengths of the buses are given as input, and prove that this version of the problem is NP-hard. Finally, we conclude with some open problems in Sect. 6.

1.0.1 Related Work.

The orthogonal graph drawing style has found many applications in VLSI design since its introduction inÂ [1], [2], andÂ [3]. Many optimization criteria have been suggested, such as minimizing layout area, minimizing the number of wire crossings in a layout, etc. ([4], [5])

A realization of a bus graph conveys visibility relations among the buses and connectors. Given an arrangement of points (connectors) and axis-parallel line segments (buses) on a grid, if a bus Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a connector cjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—c_{j}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be joined by a straight-line edge, then there exists an axis-parallel line of sight that does not intersect any buses or connectors except Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and cjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—c_{j}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, if all the buses are drawn horizontally, the bus graph GğºGitalic_G is a subgraph of the visibility graph representing the vertical visibility among the bus segments. There is an abundance of prior work on the visibility graphs based on axis-parallel lines of sight, for example, in [6], [7], [8], [9], [10], [11], [12], andÂ [13]. In particular, [10] and [11] study bar visibility graphs (BVGs), where each vertex in the graph is drawn as a horizontal line segment in â„2superscriptâ„2\bbbr^{2}roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the adjacency among the vertices represent vertical visibility. It is shown that the recognition problem of such graphs can be solved in linear time. In [7], [9], [8], [12], [13], the authors study rectangle visibility graphs (RVGs), where each vertex is drawn as a rectangle, and the adjacency among the vertices represent axis-parallel lines of sight. Reference [13] shows that the recognition problem of such graphs is NP-complete. The bus graphs that we study in this paper can be regarded as related to RVGs, where the vertices are restricted to degenerate rectangles such as line segments and points.

2 Preliminaries

Given a bus graph G=(â„¬,ğ’;â„°)ğºâ„¬ğ’â„°G=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ), we call a vertex BğµBitalic_B a â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertex if Bâˆˆâ„¬ğµâ„¬B\in\mathcal{B}italic_B âˆˆ caligraphic_B; its realization is called a bus. Similarly, a ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex refers to a vertex in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C, and its realization is called a connector. We often use uppercase letters to denote â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices, and lowercase letters to denote ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices.

We use a function Î“Î“\Gammaroman_Î“ to denote an embedding of a combinatorial bus graph GğºGitalic_G. For example, Î“â¢(c)Î“ğ‘\Gamma(c)roman_Î“ ( italic_c ) for some ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex cğ‘citalic_c denotes the grid point where cğ‘citalic_c is laid out in the embedding, and Î“â¢(B)Î“ğµ\Gamma(B)roman_Î“ ( italic_B ) for some â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertex BğµBitalic_B or Î“â¢((B,c))Î“ğµğ‘\Gamma((B,c))roman_Î“ ( ( italic_B , italic_c ) ) for some edge (B,c)ğµğ‘(B,c)( italic_B , italic_c ) denotes the line segment along a grid line where the bus or edge is laid out. We call a grid point an event point if there is either a connector or an endpoint of a bus at that grid point.

It is important to note here that many variations of the bus graph problem can be devised, yet several are equivalent. For example, suppose the buses are realized as open line segments. It is not hard to see that this variation is equivalent to the problem stated in Sect. 1, as an embedding with buses as open line segments can easily be transformed into an embedding with buses as closed line segments, and vice versa.

For another variation, note that a bus graph G=(â„¬,ğ’;â„°)ğºâ„¬ğ’â„°G=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ) can be regarded as a hypergraph, where â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B is the set of vertices, and ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is the set of hyperedges, each connecting at most four vertices. In this context, it is of interest to see if the realizability problem changes if we disallow multiple hyperedges in the hypergraph GğºGitalic_G. In other words, we would assume that no two ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices are adjacent to the same set of â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. As the following lemma shows, this assumption does not change our problem.

Lemma 1

Let GğºGitalic_G be a bus graph with multiple hyperedges in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C, and let Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the bus graph constructed from GğºGitalic_G by removing hyperedge duplicates. Then GğºGitalic_G is realizable if and only if Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is realizable.

Proof

Necessity is trivial. Conversely, suppose Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is realizable. Take any embedding of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and let cğ‘citalic_c be a connector in the embedding at some position (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j)( italic_i , italic_j ). Then, create a copy of cğ‘citalic_c with the same connectivity to buses as follows. For each event point in the embedding, if its xğ‘¥xitalic_x-coordinate is strictly greater than iğ‘–iitalic_i, increase its xğ‘¥xitalic_x-coordinate by 1. Then, if cğ‘citalic_c is connected to the rightmost endpoint of a horizontal bus BğµBitalic_B, where the endpoint is at an xğ‘¥xitalic_x-coordinate equal to iğ‘–iitalic_i, increase the xğ‘¥xitalic_x-coordinate of the endpoint by 1. 3 NP-Completeness

3.1 Membership in NP

Lemma 2

Bus graph realizability is in NP.

Proof

First, we claim that if a bus graph GğºGitalic_G is realizable, there exists a compact layout such that the size of the layout is linear in each dimension. To see this, take any layout of GğºGitalic_G, and compact the layout as follows. Take a vertical grid line with no event points on it. Then, for each event point at (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y ) appearing to the right of this grid line, shift it to (xâˆ’1,y)ğ‘¥1ğ‘¦(x-1,y)( italic_x - 1 , italic_y ). Observe that this operation still guarantees a legal layout. Repeat this for each such vertical grid line. Notice that the width of the layout is now linear in the size of GğºGitalic_G. We can apply a similar operation for all such horizontal grid lines. Thus, the claim is true, so there exists a short certificate for each realizable graph GğºGitalic_G that gives the coordinates of the event points in a compact layout. It is easy to see that we can check, in polynomial time, if such a certificate represents a correct solution.âˆ

Since every gadget is of linear size, the transformation clearly takes polynomial time. Finally, the following lemma completes the proof of TheoremÂ 1.1.

Lemma 7

4 Applications of Proof Techniques

In this section, we look at variations of the bus graph realizability problem in which the degree of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is restricted. In the original bus graph realizability problem presented in Sect. 1, each ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex has a maximum degree of 4, due to the orthogonal drawing style. An analogous problem can be devised for the class of bus graphs where the ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices have maximum degrees of either 2 or 3. In what follows, we show that these variations are also NP-complete. Finally, we discuss the problem of merely deciding the orientation of buses, which also turns out to be NP-complete.

4.1 Connectors with Bounded Degree

First, consider the class of bus graphs where the ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices have maximum degree 1. These graphs are trivially realizable by simply drawing all the buses along a grid line. However, if the maximum degree of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is greater than or equal to 2, the problem becomes harder. Recall from the proof of TheoremÂ 1.1 in Sect. 3 that the reduction from NAE-3SAT was done using a series of gadgets, each of which was based on the (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp. The following results follow from constructing an (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp gadget for each case, and then constructing the remaining gadgets in a similar fashion.

Theorem 4.1

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete when the maximum degree of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is 2.

Proof sketch.

If every ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex has degree 2, we may regard each ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex as an edge connecting two â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. Thus, in the following description, when we say to join two â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices, we mean to create a ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex that joins the two â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. To construct the perp gadget, start with a complete graph K8subscriptğ¾8K_{8}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with vertices labeled B1subscriptğµ1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT through B8subscriptğµ8B_{8}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, create another vertex B9subscriptğµ9B_{9}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and join it with vertices B1subscriptğµ1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT through B7subscriptğµ7B_{7}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, create a vertex B10subscriptğµ10B_{10}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and join it to vertices B1subscriptğµ1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT through B6subscriptğµ6B_{6}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, B8subscriptğµ8B_{8}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and B9subscriptğµ9B_{9}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It can be shown that the buses B8subscriptğµ8B_{8}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and B10subscriptğµ10B_{10}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be drawn perpendicularly to each other, and all other gadgets can be constructed based on this structure.111 For obvious reasons, we cannot use a single ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex to represent a clause. This can be resolved by creating a combination of perp gadgets and (I,O)ğ¼ğ‘‚(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chains. âˆ

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete, when the maximum degree of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is 3.

Our results can be summarized as follows.

Theorem 4.3

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete if and only if the maximum degree of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices in the given graph is 2, 3, or 4.

4.2 Partition by Orientation

In order to realize a given bus graph, one must decide the orientations of the buses. Since a connector can be joined to at most two horizontal buses and at most two vertical buses, all realizable bus graphs admit a bipartition of buses by orientation. As we will see shortly, even deciding whether the buses can be properly oriented is hard to compute. Note, however, that a proper bipartition by orientation does not guarantee that the graph is realizable.222 A simple counterexample can be constructed by first creating a complete graph with 9 â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices, and then placing a ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex on each edge.

We define the problem PARTITION-BY-ORIENTATION as follows:

Instance: A bipartite graph G=(â„¬,ğ’;â„°)ğºâ„¬ğ’â„°G=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ) such that âˆ€câˆˆğ’for-allğ‘ğ’\forall c\in\mathcal{C}âˆ€ italic_c âˆˆ caligraphic_C, dâ¢eâ¢gâ¢(c)â‰¤4ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘4deg(c)\leq 4italic_d italic_e italic_g ( italic_c ) â‰¤ 4.

Question: Can â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B be partitioned into two disjoint sets â„¬â„‹subscriptâ„¬â„‹\mathcal{B_{H}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„¬ğ’±subscriptâ„¬ğ’±\mathcal{B_{V}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that âˆ€câˆˆğ’for-allğ‘ğ’\forall c\in\mathcal{C}âˆ€ italic_c âˆˆ caligraphic_C, cğ‘citalic_c is adjacent to no more than two vertices in â„¬â„‹subscriptâ„¬â„‹\mathcal{B_{H}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and no more than two vertices in â„¬ğ’±subscriptâ„¬ğ’±\mathcal{B_{V}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT?

Theorem 4.4

PARTITION-BY-ORIENTATION is NP-complete.

Proof

The problem is clearly in NP, as one could guess a partition and check for its correctness in polynomial time. For the reduction, we use NAE-3SAT. Given an instance Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• of NAE-3SAT, we construct a graph GğºGitalic_G as follows. 5 Bus Graph Realizability with Given Bus Lengths

In this section, we study a variation of bus graph realizability in which the lengths of buses are given as input (BGR+BL). We devise a new encoding scheme for the instances of this problem. The purpose of this encoding scheme will become clear shortly. Recall from the discussion in Sect. 2 that bus graphs can be regarded as hypergraphs, where each ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex corresponds to a hyperedge. In the new encoding scheme, we assume that the problem instance is given as a list of subsets of â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B, where each subset is of cardinality at most 4. For each subset, we also encode the number of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices that are adjacent to exactly that subset of â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. Notice that this is a form of adjacency matrix for the hypergraph, where each entry in the matrix denotes the number of hyperedges for that particular subset of buses. In the case of hypergraphs where no multiple hyperedges are allowed, each entry in the matrix would be either 1 or 0.

Now we are ready to state and prove the main result of this section.

Theorem 5.1

BGR+BL is NP-hard. It is also NP-hard if the maximum degree of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is 2, or if we require the buses to be parallel to each other.

Proof

The reduction is from PARTITIONÂ [14]. 6 Concluding Remarks and Open Problems

Although bus graph realizability is an NP-complete problem in general, some special classes of graphs admit polynomial time solutions. For example, if the given bus graph GğºGitalic_G is a tree, it is simple to devise an algorithm to produce a realization of GğºGitalic_G, and hence GğºGitalic_G always admits a bus graph embedding. However, what other classes of graphs admit polynomial time recognition algorithms for realizable bus graphs is an unexplored question.

As a consequence of the hardness results of this paper, one may search for approximate solutions to the problems. It is unclear, however, what optimization criteria would be used. With applications in VLSI in mind, one may wish to lay out all the buses first, and then maximize the connectivity by maximizing the number of connectors realized in the layout.

Appendix: Necessity Proof for LemmaÂ 7

In this section, a full proof for the necessity of the LemmaÂ 7 is given. Let Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• denote a boolean formula for NAE-3SAT, consisting of nğ‘›nitalic_n variables and mğ‘šmitalic_m clauses, and let Ïƒ:Xâ†’{T,F}:ğœâ†’ğ‘‹ğ‘‡ğ¹\sigma:X\rightarrow\{T,F\}italic_Ïƒ : italic_X â†’ { italic_T , italic_F } be a satisfying truth assignment for Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•. Given Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, our goal is to show that the bus graph GğºGitalic_G, constructed from the transformation shown in Sect. 3.2, is realizable. We first describe how each gadget, as introduced in Sect. 3.1, can be embedded within a bounding box of predefined size. Then, the overall embedding of GğºGitalic_G is presented by explicitly giving coordinates for each gadget bounding box. Finally, we show that the so-described embedding of GğºGitalic_G is a legal layout of a bus graph, which completes the proof. For simplicity, we often refer to a bounding box as an nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times nitalic_n Ã— italic_n subgrid, which is a square of size (nâˆ’1)Ã—(nâˆ’1)ğ‘›1ğ‘›1(n-1)\times(n-1)( italic_n - 1 ) Ã— ( italic_n - 1 ), with nğ‘›nitalic_n grid points along each side.

Note that the coordinates used in this section are relative to each corresponding gadget only.

C. Correctness of the Embedding

In this section, we show that the embedding of GğºGitalic_G is a legal layout. To do this, we refer back to the four properties stated in the problem definition in Sect. 1. The first two properties hold trivially by construction. Hence, it suffices to show that the other two properties hold.

Proof

We check if the properties hold as we lay out each gadget. By construction, the embedding of each individual gadget is legal. So first lay out the variable boxes and clause boxes. The embedding of these boxes together is legal, since no two boxes overlap. Now, lay out the (I,O)ğ¼ğ‘‚(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chains and see if the two properties still hold.

(Property 3.) We say an edge passes through a gadget if the embedded edge enters and exits the bounding box of the gadget. Since each bus or connector is drawn within the bounding box of a gadget, we need to show that no edge passes through a gadget. Note that we need only consider the edges along the (I,O)ğ¼ğ‘‚(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chains, as all other edges are embedded inside gadget bounding boxes. Notice that for each flipper fğ‘“fitalic_f in some (I,O)ğ¼ğ‘‚(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chain in the embedding, fğ‘“fitalic_f is joined to other components by a horizontal edge fHsubscriptğ‘“ğ»f_{H}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a vertical edge fVsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‰f_{V}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Now, take a horizontal edge eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on some grid line y=y1ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦1y=y_{1}italic_y = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There are three cases to consider. (1) Suppose eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT passes through a flipper fğ‘“fitalic_f in some (I,O)ğ¼ğ‘‚(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chain. Then eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be fewer than 4 grid lines apart from fHsubscriptğ‘“ğ»f_{H}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is a contradiction, as any two horizontal edges in the embedding are at least 9 grid lines apart from each other. (2) Suppose eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT passes through a variable box. If y1>0subscriptğ‘¦10y_{1}>0italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, there is exactly one variable box at y=y1ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦1y=y_{1}italic_y = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT connects to at its endpoint. If y1â‰¤0subscriptğ‘¦10y_{1}\leq 0italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot reach any variable box because all variable boxes are above the xğ‘¥xitalic_x-axis. This is a contradiction. (3) Suppose eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT passes through a clause box. If y1â‰¤0subscriptğ‘¦10y_{1}\leq 0italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, there is exactly one clause box at y=y1ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦1y=y_{1}italic_y = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT connects to at its endpoint. If y1>0subscriptğ‘¦10y_{1}>0italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, eHsubscriptğ‘’ğ»e_{H}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot reach any clause box because all clause boxes are below the yğ‘¦yitalic_y-axis, hence a contradiction.

(Property 4.) We say two gadgets intersect if the bounding boxes of the two embedded gadgets intersect. Since each bus or connector is embedded within some gadget, if no two gadgets intersect then no buses or connectors may intersect. We categorize the gadgets into 5 types as follows.

  1. 1.

    Type-Q1subscriptğ‘„1Q_{1}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT flipper: a flipper embedded in the first quadrant

  3. 3.

    Type-Q4subscriptğ‘„4Q_{4}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT flipper: a flipper embedded in the fourth quadrant

  4. 4.

    a variable box

  5. 5.

    a clause box

It is easy to check that each gadget belongs the exactly one of these types. By construction, no two gadgets of the same type may intersect.
